title: Express Talk: Inca-period Textiles of the Andes
hero_caption: Poncho, 1476/1532. Chuquibamba, possibly Ica Valley, south coast, Peru. Ada Turnbull Hertle Endowment.
description:
In the 1400s, the Incas began a century-long campaign to conquer much of the central Andes Mountains. One thing that made them so successful was their distinctive, imperial artistic style. Join Andrew J. Hamilton, associate curator of arts of the Americas, and learn how an impressive Chuquibamba-style textile from Peru’s southern coast expresses both Inca and pre-Inca artistic traditions.

Persons with disabilities who would like to request an accessibility accommodation for an Art Institute program are encouraged to send an email to access@artic.edu two weeks in advance of the program. 

Please note that the image on this page is for reference purposes only and may not be featured during the gallery talk.
